title: Shakib Al Hasan responds after receiving two-year cricket ban
text:
Shakib Al Hasan has been hit with a two-year ban from cricket (Picture: Getty Images)

Shakib Al Hasan ‘completely accepts’ his ban from all cricket – lasting two years with one suspended – after breaching the ICC’s Anti-Corruption Code.

The Bangladesh captain accepted three charges of failing to disclose approaches to engage in corrupt conduct to the ICC’s Anti-Corruption Unit, all made in 2018.

The 32-year-old will be out of action until 29 October as a result of the ban, as long as he does not trigger the suspended year before then.

‘I am obviously extremely sad to have been banned from the game I love,’ said Al Hasan. ‘But I completely accept my sanction for not reporting the approaches. The ICC ACU is reliant on players to play a central part in the fight against corruption and I didn’t do my duty in this instance.

‘Like the majority of players and fans around the world, I want cricket to be a corruption free sport and I am looking forward to working with the ICC ACU team to support their education programme and ensure young players don’t make the same mistake I did.’

Alex Marshall, ICC General Manager – Integrity said of the ban: ‘Shakib Al Hasan is a highly experienced international cricketer. He has attended many education sessions and knows his obligations under the Code. He should have reported each of these approaches.

‘Shakib has accepted his errors and cooperated fully with the investigation. He has offered to assist the Integrity Unit in future education, to help younger players to learn from his mistakes. I am happy to accept this offer.’

The ban will keep the all-rounder out of the Indian Premier League, Pakistan Super League and Bangladesh Premier League, all of which he has commitments to.

He will also miss Bangladesh’s upcoming fixtures against India and the start of the Twenty20 World Cup next year.
